Measures general mental ability, or G, and effectively measures candidates’ problem-solving and critical reasoning capabilities.
SHL Verify Deductive Reasoning
Measures candidates’ ability to draw logical conclusions and complete scenarios based on the information provided. Tasks include reading statements, then determining which subsequent options cannot be true or must be true.
SHL Verify Interactive – Inductive Reasoning
Measures candidates’ ability to draw inferences from, and understand relationships between, various concepts. Tasks include working out the pattern in a set of images and identifying the correct next image.
SHL Verify Interactive – Numerical Reasoning
Measures candidates’ ability to work with numbers and use appropriate mathematics in different situations. Tasks include solving word problems, performing numerical calculations, and interpreting charts and graphs.

Frequently Asked Questions
The solution works best when making candidate selections towards the end of the hiring process. It helps you run structured interviews to select the right candidates to progress through to the offer stage, and delivers interviewer analytics to continually improve interviewing outcomes.
If you have a high volume of candidates, and need to create a shortlist to progress further to second-stage interviews, our Smart Interview on Demand solution is ideal. Candidates record responses to your interview questions at their own convenience, and our solution automates scoring to enable you to review thousands of candidates in minutes.
We recommend structured interviews. A structured interview is a consistent and standardized process where all candidates are asked the same predetermined questions in the same order. Each candidate’s responses are also scored with the same pre-determined rating scale. In other words, they have structure built into the way the interview is conduced and the way the candidate is cored.
By comparison, unstructured interviews are more conversational, where the goal is to get to know the person and ask questions about the role as you go. The questions asked may be tailored to the specific candidate based on their background or experience, and because this style of interview is so relaxed, no two interviews for the same job are the same.
Structured interviews are consistent, repeatable and scalable. So when they are executed correctly you will reduce bias and improve comparability between candidates. They are scientifically proven to be one of the most predictive tools for assessing job performance – five times more effective at predicting job performance than unstructured interviews. They are also considerably more efficient. Research shows it takes between three and four unstructured interviews to match the accuracy of data from a single structured interview.
An interview guide is a roadmap for you or your team, which contains all the structure and elements of your interview process. The guide keeps on your track during every interview and is essential to running a structured interview. Without the interview guide it’s easy to lose focus, skip important questions, or spend too much time on less relevant details. It also keeps the scoring criteria front of mind.
With Smart Interview Professional, it’s easy to create the interview guide. We recommend competencies and skills to assess in the interview using just a few pieces of information, such as the job title. Once you’ve selected the important things to evaluate in the interview, you’re able to select questions to measure these competencies and skills from our library of questions. We have mapped science-backed interview questions to more than 800 job roles and also have an option to use AI to read a job description and align the appropriate interview questions with that. In addition, you can add questions specific to your company values.
Within the interview guide, Smart Interview Professional also has a scoring framework and guide for each question, plus the ability to record notes and scores alongside each question.
Structured interviews is among the strongest predictors of future job success, but other objective methods of assessment – like personality, skills and cognitive ability assessments – are still essential to give you additional relevant data to use to find the best candidates in your applicant pool.

Frequently Asked Questions
Experience is often the first thing that talent acquisition professionals look for when hiring professionals. However, it does not indicate whether the individual will successfully integrate into the team and how likely they are to stay at the organization. And the evidence suggests that the idea that candidates with more experience will perform better and go on to be long-tenured employees is unfounded. The more important takeaway should be – has the candidate learned from their previous experiences? It’s vital that hiring managers evaluate how candidates have dealt with situations in the past.
Often one of the reasons that employers look for candidates with experience is that they think previous jobs have helped those people build up knowledge and skills. But we’d recommend focusing on the knowledge, skills and personality traits directly rather than using experience as a proxy for these.
We believe that candidates are so much more than their resume. A data-driven approach using objective measurement gives a full picture of the individual and enables you to understand their capability based on their readiness to do the job today, their fit with your organization as well as their future potential for growth and impact.
We define readiness as the capability of a candidate relative to day one of a specific job role. It comprises the hard and soft skills, and the knowledge that will allow the individual to be successful against the needs of the job right away.
A candidate’s potential refers to their capacity to develop into something further — and it’s an important consideration if succession planning and promotability are important.
Fit refers to culture fit, company fit and team fit and its importance increases if you need to tackle turnover, drive higher engagement, or add rigor to the cultural experience of your employees.
By measuring all of these three elements in an experienced hire, you’re more likely to select the individuals that will thrive in their role and stay longer at your organization.
And that’s in addition to objective measurement also helping you to remove bias from the selection process and making it easier to compare candidates against each other, removing the guesswork from hiring decisions.
One of the biggest challenges for HR leaders is the level of change in organizations. Roles are evolving at an unprecedented rate which means that the shelf life of some skills is shrinking as new skill requirements come to the fore. This means that the ability to assess and understand an individual’s reskilling potential has never been more crucial, as the traditional skills that once guaranteed success are no longer sufficient. Even experienced hires need to have the ability to learn and adapt to new technologies in the future.
That’s why we’ve built a measure into our professional hiring solution that will give you a comprehensive view of both the individual’s critical skills needed for today and their ability and willingness to pick up new skills for the future. This foresight can be the difference between a workforce that thrives and one that becomes obsolete.
With experience under their belts, candidates are likely to have a clear picture of what they want from their career and their next employer. While they will have already been more selective with their applications, you can stand out on their shortlist by building a stronger connection with the candidate throughout the hiring experience.
With our hiring platform, there are two quick ways to build engagement early in the recruitment phases. Firstly, showcase your company’s mission and values through videos of existing experienced hires which can be presented to the candidates at any stage in the hiring process. And secondly, provide auto-generated personalized feedback to every candidate, immediately – helping them to feel that the process has been a valuable experience for them, whatever the outcome.
